comments.commentBody: This can't be as much fun as trying to sneak into Hitachi bomb-detection facilities in Yokahama, but there are worse jobs.
so?  this way of thinking is flawed and racist in its own right.  it is supposed to be about QUALIFICATIONS and NOT COLOR............

There is a general belief that there are standards that apply equally to all of us and that those standards are not linked to specific peoples and social structures. Not even math, the purest of disciplines, is totally disconnected from contexts, peoples, society.

A linguist once asked me if it was true what Cubans say about Puerto Ricans, that we are a very docile group of people. Had this conversation taken place in a bodega it would have been quite normal to speak off the top of your head, though it showed a limited thinking capacity when it came to human nature. Bu this conversation was taking place in a higher education institution and in a program teaching courses on socio linguistics, a field dedicated to the formulation and codification of concepts. Obviously, this linguist was not up to the standards required to understand how language evolves and its relationship to power structures, much less able to work with Puerto Ricans students if this was his view of the given ethnic groups. Yet, there he was in a position where he has been hired as a leader on his file but unable to apply his knowledge to specific situations. Quite often getting caught up with the standards do not let you see the details that support or modify such standards.

Quotas are one thing, bringing people who hold different experiences and histories to work together in a given situation are another. I am sure the major can find non-white individuals who are very well prepared who will enrich and improve his decisions, his actions, his own thinking.

God, so many of you people are spoiled little kids. We should be lucky that we live in a city that still has public services and not in crisis, unlike many west coast cities. Times are rough and the city is still staying a float, and crime levels are still low.

To those people making the argument about his third term being illegal, I guess that amendment the state legislature made was just as illegal as changing the 13th amendment to the US Constitution.

As long as the city in running, especially in these grim economic times, he's doing the job like it or not.

If you dont like it, put your money where your mouth is and run in about 3 years.
Why do we have to have diversity in everything?   If whites are the best fit for the job, hire whites.

Another disgraceful race-baiting article from the NY Times, completely devoid of any actual reporting...such as evidence that the people Bloomberg has hired are actually less competent minorities who deserve those positions.
You mean the Gospel Choir, Magic Johnson and the room full of blues people at the victory night celebration were duped - or were they props?

So competency should make way for diversity--is that what we want?

Bloomberg should choose whoever he feels would best serve the city. Bloomberg does not need nags like you to tell him he needs diversity.

They said that French victory in 1998 would help racial relations and it did.... for a very short time. South African problems are so much deeper, any positive effect of the World Cup will be gone in a few months. After all, it's just a game.

Something else you said - "Jobs do not lie in digging more stuff out the ground" - I find it so snobbish and condescending. If US government did not subsidize American farmers, maybe African farmers would have a chance at a better life.
This was a great decision by the Supreme Court.  The NY Times seems to prefer a system in which the criminals have the guns, but the innocent victims don't.  Look how this turned out in Chicago.

Monday's SCOTUS decision is one of the finest in my lifetime.  It was a great ruling in favor of freedom and individual liberty, and a great warning against the prospects of governmental tyranny.  I intend to make a sizable donation, this week,  to a specific deserving entity, in acknowledgemt of this monumental ruling.

I realize that for Democrats and other control-freak statists, that this enlightened Supreme Court decision is frightening.  But, for those of us who are true civil libertarians, this is a wonderful ruling.  Oh Happy Day.
@Wags, a penguin trying to apply lipstick?

You say "what good would it have done him" but it is us who gets the advantages of knowledge from the ages.  Observed knowledge is how we have gotten to the 21st century with the smarts we have.  Otherwise we would still think the earth is flat.  Oh.. sorry.. some still do!  JT

I am thinking that my success has to do with another
form of wandering which was not addressed in this report ,that
is called procrastination.
I learned it from a rather famous screenwriter who became lost
at script deadline time, lost of course was avoiding people till
he was satisfied the script was finished.
Very thought provoking I wonder how I got that stain on this necktie column, but I wonder how I'll not another ED commercial ever be able to use it.
My wandering mind came up with line as the connector - as in eye liner and the lining of a gown or a basket lined in fabric.
Wow.  Obama makes Bush look like an intellectual giant.  Hippies, enough with the 'military-industrial' complex.  If the military got its way, these wars would have been over long ago.
I also thought of Little Red Riding Hood.

God, it seems that these folks can get a grant to study anything. But something this obvious?
http://emcphd.wordpress.com/

The "eye, gown, basket" was standard quiz fare, can you guess what a person of high but bounded intelligence wants you to guess? A good wanderer would move from camel's toes to that meal they missed in Morocco, and not care in the least how well they played the game of Simon Says set up by the test giver.

Trying to rationalize "eye, gown, basket" misses the point.  I thought nothing of it.  And I am a person who gets paid handsomely listening to people all day and I don't even like listening to people.

After reading this article, I've had an epiphany:  the writers at "Jeopardy" are mind-wanders of the highest creative order!  Plus, I'm relieved to know that I am not alone in mind wandering while reading "War and Peace," which I have yet to get through despite having started it three times.  Although, I was able to finish "The Idiot," but I couldn't tell you what it is about. :)

I've embedded as a freelance photojournalist in Iraq several times. I'm also an Army veteran of Desert Storm, so I understand a variety of the objectivity concerns.

I don't really agree with Hersh. Really, his statement covers anything - if a reporter covers a small town's board of selectmen, he/she gets to know them on a friendly basis and will probably feel bad if a story would jam them up. A reporter who can't be objective with soldiers probably can't be objective back home either.

During my embeds, I had it much easier than someone like Hastings. My goal was to write stories about junior soldiers, which I would then freelance to their hometown newspapers - I was not chasing profiles of senior leaders. I was providing less 'news' and more 'color.'

However, the goal was still to be truthful - obviously.

In most/all cases, the average E-4 is perfectly happy to vent all day long - if I wanted to only print verbatim quotes, they could look pretty bad. My job, then, is ensure I provide CONTEXT - so a soldier might say "I hate this, this is the stupidest mission in the stupidest country, and every minute I regret enlisting," BUT if they say it while on their 18th hour in full gear guarding a MRAP that got stuck in a road that the tow truck can't get down...well, what would you expect them to say?

So in that example, that quote's perfectly fine. It doesn't put the soldier in a bad light, but a human light - if anything, the reader could relate to the event that much more because of COURSE he's complaining, and it's something the average civilian reader cannot conceive. So, hopefully, the reader appreciates the situation these men have found themselves in.

But if I just quoted that in some random part of the story? Without the explanation of the stuck MRAP? Well, obviously I'm an (expletive of choice).

So in Hasting's case, what was he supposed to do? They took him out drinking with them! That WAS the context. So should he ignore it? Be one of the guys? He's NOT one of the guys. He's never going to be one of the guys.

None of the officers I talked with ever made the "mistake" of being disrespectful to higher command. They didn't put themselves in the position of McC's staff. Would I have done something with it it, if they had? Depends on the context - I'm not going to tailor an entire story just so I can justify using an otherwise out-of-context quote.

The only thing a soldier ever explicity asked me not to use (other than security concerns) was a dirty joke.

Now, I'm sympathetic, so I go back and forth on finding fault with Hastings. Part of me is like, "come on, they took you out drinking, couldn't you be cool?" But then another part is like, "they took you out drinking? You gotta write that!"

In 2007, junior soldiers I met were bitter and cynical and happy to tell me so. We were in a JSS that was mortared every day, and they sat there and took it. It was absolutely horrible. They were not believers in the reconcilation mission and were confident we would fail. They looked at meetings over chai tea in the most bitter terms possible.

From the stories I then wrote, a couple guys got in semi-trouble with their command for quotes, and for pictures w/unauthorized stuff on their uniforms.

It wasn't serious trouble - but ANY trouble adds a level of stress to an already awful situation.

I re-embedded with the same unit again, two years later, and saw some of those guys again.

They then had the opportunity to tell me - right to my face - what they thought of me and the stuff I wrote. But - they all liked the stories, and they told me they liked them because what I wrote was true; if they got in trouble, they didn't mind, because it was their words and they were telling their own story.

And, two years removed from the awful 2007 deployment, they could now see that the meetings they hated actually had positive developments, and they could put their experiences into their own more meaningful context. They stood by their earlier words, but now understood events from a different perspective.

Soldiers (and I was one) appreciate the truth. The one thing I definitley fault Hastings for is not using the names of the guys he talked to...what, McC can take the fall, but not his staff? If you say it, stand by it. I don't respect anonymous sources in most government stories - especially from sources speaking from power. It's a disgraceful, cowardly practice, really.

Having said that, I was writing from a much more limiting perspective than Hastings. So I didn't have to make the same kind of compromises. So I'm judging - but I don't have his perspective, or know the context of his conversations.

I understand Hersh's basic point, about writing objectively about the guys (and women) who are protecting an embed reporter. But, the same could be said for reporting on police and firemen. You either want to tell a true story based on facts, or you don't. It's not hard.

Very interesting insight into Mc Crystal's charcter when it is shown that the only person he did not disparage was Hillary Clinton who uncritically supported him without question.  Also gives a clue to Clinton's cluelessness.
